items.item_details:
Item:  9.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent 
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. on a Charter School Petition Renewal Submitted by Escuela Popular
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
Public Charter Schools are approved initially for up to a five (5) year period and at the end of that time must apply for a charter school renewal for a term of five (5) years and continue to apply for renewal after each five (5) year term. Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within thirty (30) days following the submission of a renewal charter school petition to the district.  The renewal petition was submitted to the district on February 16, 2012.
	 
During the Public Hearing the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  The Governing Board shall either grant or deny the charter renewal within sixty (60) days of receipt of the petition; however, the date may be extended by an additional thirty (30) days if both parties agree to the extension.  Such agreement has been reached and at the April 19, 2012 Board Meeting the Governing Board shall make its determination.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE: 
Part of Review Process
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
Part of Review Process
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold Public Hearing to consider level of support for the petition renewal submitted by Escuela Popular.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.02
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
	 
SUBJECT:                    Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m.
	                                    Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From East Side Union
                                    High School District to East Side Teachers Association
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association for the 2012-2013 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2012-2013 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; reduction of work year, and class size.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board sunshine and accept any comment on the District’s initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  11.03
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-24 Joint Powers Authority Membership - School Project for Utility Rate Reduction
			 
 
The District continues to seek and review opportunities to reduce utility costs and increase efficiencies, including but not limited to the costs of natural gas and other fuels, electricity, telecommunications, water and sewage, and waste hauling.  This resolution is specifically related to natural gas and allows the district to declare its membership in the School Project for Utility Rate Reduction (SPURR), a California joint powers authority, and instructs its duly authorized agent to execute and deliver on its behalf any necessary or appropriate documents to carry out the intent of this resolution, including the SPURR Joint Powers Agreement and any agreements necessary to participate in programs operated by SPURR.
			 
SPURR is a widely recognized schools and colleges natural gas JPA in California and by joining the JPA, the district is expecting to save thousands as part of this pooling program for natural gas purchasing.  
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Savings (Natural Gas) to be Determined 
			 
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2011/2012-24 Joint Powers Authority Membership - School Project for Utility Rate Reduction.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction; Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services; and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary Education
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve 2012 Summer School Program
	 
	 
The ESUHSD summer school program window will begin June 11, 2012 and end July 20, 2012 (no school on Monday, July 4th), and will be available for incoming 9th grade students and our Special Needs students at risk of failing the High School Exit Exam (CAHSEE) and for eligible students in Special Education, and non-graduating seniors through Adult Education.
	 
The estimated reimbursement from the State is based on 81.6 percent of the 2007-08 funding for Supplemental Instruction.  Additionally, the Supplemental Instruction fund is part of the Tier III Categorical Program, which allows the fund to be "swept" to help augment the general fund and to allow for greater flexibility in its use by districts.
	 
A description of the summer school programs are described below:
	 
1.  At-Risk incoming 9th graders
The goals of the 9th grade summer programs are to prepare students who are not demonstrating sufficient progress towards passing the CAHSEE for success in Algebra 1 and English 1, articulate with feeder school teachers about student achievement and curriculum focused on CAHSEE standards, and to provide professional development on best practices relating to teaching strategies and curriculum designed to prepare students for rigor of high school.
	 
2.  Special Education
Special Education classes will be offered at WCO, AH, JL, and YB High Schools for Special Day Class (SDC) students who qualify for Extended School Year (ESY) Services per their IEP. Funding for the SDC students is provided through a daily allocation from the State Department.
	 
The ESY program will begin Thursday, June 21, 2012 and ends on Thursday, July 19th 2012 for a total of 20 days.
	 
		 
		 
Summer School Sites:
The following school sites are being recommended as locations for summer school during the summer of 2012:
Andrew Hill High School                
Independence High School           
James Lick High School
Mt. Pleasant High School
OakGrove High School       
W.C. Overfelt High School
Yerba Buena High School       
	 
Summer School Bell Schedule:
	 
Period 1         7:50 a.m.  -  10:10 a.m. (140 min.)
“B” Period    10:10 a.m.  -  10:35 a.m. (20 min.)
Period 2       10:40 a.m.  -   1:00  p.m. (140 min.)
	 
	 
3.  Adult Education:
Adult Education classes will be offered at Independence Adult Center for non-graduating seniors.  Classes begin June 4, 2012 and end on June 29, 2012.
	 
	 
Summer School Bell Schedule:
	 
Session 1      8:00 a.m. - 10:30 a.m.
Break           10:30 a.m. - 10:50 a.m.
Session 2    10:50 a.m. - 12:50 a.m.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
$500,000* (estimated)
*To be amended at a later date, if necessary.
		 
FUNDING SOURCE
State Summer School Allocation
(Supplemental Instruction Program)
Adult Education
		 
The East Side Teachers Association and California School Employee Association have been consulted and support this recommendation.
		 
		 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the 2012 Summer School Program as indicated herein, and that the Superintendent be authorized to make modifications as needed.

PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Andrew Schwab, Director of Information Technology
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Presentation/Update on Information Technology
					 
			 
The presentation is an update of Information Technology for the District. The IT Services Department supports teachers and students in their everyday use of technology in the classroom as well as district and school operations. The Student Information System migration and the SmartBoard Professional Development Measure E IT projects have been completed and the wireless project is underway.  Through Measure E IT funds, 1,240 new computers have been purchased for schools as have 59 SmartBoards, 227 document cameras and 230 digital projectors.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  14.02
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Board Approval of Second Interim Financial Report for FY 2011-12
			 
			 
			 
This is the second of two Interim Reports to be presented to the Governing Board for the 2011-12 fiscal year.  The report provides the Board with the financial status of the district as of January 31, 2012.  This report is presented to the Board to provide the current fiscal status of the district and to meet the fiscal accountability requirements of AB 1200.  
			 
Included in the accompanying binder is an executive summary which summarizes the financial data from the SACS reporting system and budget assumptions that provide the basis for determining the District’s fiscal status.  In addition, there are supporting documentation and comparative analysis of the 2011/12 First Interim vs. Second Interim Update as of January 31, 2012, multi-year projections, state reporting forms, and other related documents.  These documents and worksheets serve as tools to certify the ongoing fiscal health of the District for this current year as well as the two subsequent fiscal years.  
			 
California school district revenues and expenditures are subject to constant change.  School district budgets are not static documents, but instead are constantly revised to respond to decisions and actions at the state, local, and federal levels.  The First Interim Report financial projections have been updated to reflect new information received and board actions taken since the Budget was adopted.  
			 
Education Code Section 42131 requires that the Governing Board of each school district certify in writing within 45 days after the close of the period being reported, whether or not the school district is able to meet its financial obligations for the remainder of the fiscal year and subsequent two fiscal years.  The certification is classified as either positive, qualified, or negative.   
			 
Based on the Districts Second Interim report and multi-year projections as of January 31, 2012, I am recommending that the Board approve the attached positive certification for the East Side Union High School District.  Your approval will provide certification to the State ensuring that the District is able to meet its financial obligations for the current fiscal year and subsequent two fiscal years.  
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Second Interim Financial Report as present for Fiscal Year 2011-12.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  14.03
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-25 regarding 2012-13 Governor's Budget - Contingency Planning
			 
			 
			 
In light of the Governor's proposed tax initiative which provides for a $370 per ADA revenue take-back in the event the initiative fails, the Governing Board for ESUHSD believes that appropriate contingency planning is critical.   The attached resolution represents the Board's commitment to provide for contingency planning in order to maintain such continuity of programs and services and fiscal solvency.  The Board acknowledges that the District will address the need for contingency planning with the appropriate Board options by which to address a potential $370 per ADA or $8.5 million in on-going revenue limit income.
			 
A more refined and specific plan will be submitted with the District’s 2012-13 Adopted Budget based upon the budget planning recommendation issued by the Santa Clara County Office of Education.  Any additional updates to that plan will be dependent on the adopted 2012-13 State Budget.
 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2011/2012-25 regarding 2012-13 Governor's Budget - Contingency Planning.

TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
							 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
							 
							 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
							 
							 
SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of February 2012
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of February 2012, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the Board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
				 
				 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
				 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
				 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Warrant Register for the month of February 2012.
